results.title: Delilah
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Famous women of the past”
Aided by the art of famous painters, this documentary tells the tail of Delilah, the biblical character, outcast and lover of Samson. Victim of savage gossip, she is burnt to death by Samson’s jealous Philistines.

results.title: Boadicea
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Documentary film about the history of Boadicea and the Roman occupation of England portrayed through various works of art.

results.title: Cleopatra and Antony
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt, friend and lover of Caesar, Roman Emperor. He is murdered, but she has a son, Caesarion. She is determined to have Caesar’s nephew, Octavian, (Emperor of Rome), removed and Caesarean in his place. To help the process she tries to befriend Mark Antony, the great Roman warrior. Antony succumbs to Cleopatra, and their relationship becomes unbreakable. Antony declares war on Rome to bring Caesarion to the throne - but after ten years of war, does not succeed, and their tragic deaths soon follow.

results.title: Cleopatra
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
A narrated account of Cleopatra’s war against her younger brother, Ptolemy, and her later influence on Julius Caesar. The film uses paints of historical events and classical music adds dramatic effect.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 8
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
Cinemagazine items: 1. UN at work on world wide system of road signs - An amusing allegory with cartoons by Steinburg. Explains how the two different systems used in Europe and America make it difficult for a travelling motorist to find their way outside their own country. 2. Eritrea federated to Ethiopia - Explains how United Nations investigated political problems posed by Eritrea, a former Italian colony on the Red Sea. The population was divided in race and religion; the land poor; political opinions strongly divided; some sought independence; some wanted union with Ethiopia. After the report by a UN Commission, the General Assembly decided to federate the country to Ethiopia within two years.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 16
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
The people of Afghanistan have followed a way of life that has changed very little in the past thousand years. In 1950 the Afghanistan Government, which has been making efforts to develop and improve the country, called upon the U.N. to help by providing technical assistance. This film describes how new knowledge and techniques have been introduce into industry and agriculture, resulting in increasing output and development of resources.

results.title: Screen Magazine. No. 13. Help for Pakistan
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
When Pakistan became an independent country in 1947, help was need by the United Nations to develop the land more extensively and establish industries. It was the people themselves who first received help from the UN. As a result of the Technical Assistance Schemes of the United Nations, Pakistanis are making more of the things they once imported, thus achieving a balance between agriculture and industry.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 12
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. Fundamental education - Mexico has developed a Fundamental Education Program which has resulted in the raising of living standards in the country and the establishment of a Training Centre for representatives from other Latin-American nations. 2. United nations stamps - On 24th October 1951, the United Nations issued its first stamp. This film shows the designing and printing of the stamps and points out their significance as they pass freely over all frontiers.
